name: Electromagnetic Field Equations
description: Exploring the mathematical relationships governing electric and magnetic fields.

cards.title: Coulomb's Law & Electric Force
cards.description: Understanding how charged particles interact through electrostatic forces.
bulletpoints: Use Coulomb's Law to calculate the force between two point charges: \[ F = k_e \frac{|q_1 q_2|}{r^2} \] where \( k_e = 8.99 \times 10^9 \) N·m²/C²
Understand how electric field strength \( E \) is defined by: \[ E = \frac{F}{q} = \frac{k_e Q}{r^2} \]
Analyze electric potential energy: \[ U = k_e \frac{q_1 q_2}{r} \]

cards.title: Lorentz Force & Motion in Magnetic Fields
cards.description: Exploring the relationship between electric charge, velocity, and magnetic forces.
bulletpoints: Apply the Lorentz force equation: \[ \mathbf{F} = q(\mathbf{E} + \mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{B}) \]
Use the right-hand rule to determine the force direction in magnetic fields.
Explore applications in electric motors and generators where \( \mathbf{F} = I \mathbf{L} \times \mathbf{B} \)

cards.title: Gauss's Law for Electric Fields
cards.description: Understanding the relationship between electric charge and electric flux.
bulletpoints: Use Gauss's Law to calculate the electric flux through a closed surface: \[ \oint \mathbf{E} \cdot d\mathbf{A} = \frac{Q_{enc}}{\epsilon_0} \]
Apply symmetry arguments to find electric fields in charge distributions.
Analyze applications in capacitors and electric shielding.

cards.title: Faraday's Law of Electromagnetic Induction
cards.description: Exploring how changing magnetic fields induce electric currents.
bulletpoints: Express Faraday's Law mathematically: \[ \mathcal{E} = - \frac{d \Phi_B}{dt} \], where \( \Phi_B = \oint \mathbf{B} \cdot d\mathbf{A} \)
Understand Lenz's Law, which states that the induced current opposes the change in flux.
Analyze applications in transformers and electromagnetic wave generation.

cards.title: Ampère's Law & Maxwell's Correction
cards.description: Understanding how electric currents and changing electric fields create magnetic fields.
bulletpoints: Use Ampère's Law: \[ \oint \mathbf{B} \cdot d\mathbf{s} = \mu_0 I_{enc} \]
Extend it to include Maxwell's displacement current term: \[ \oint \mathbf{B} \cdot d\mathbf{s} = \mu_0 \left( I_{enc} + \epsilon_0 \frac{d\Phi_E}{dt} \right) \]
Analyze how this equation unifies electricity and magnetism into a single framework.

cards.title: Poynting Vector & Energy Flow
cards.description: Exploring how energy propagates in electromagnetic fields.
bulletpoints: Define the Poynting vector as \[ \mathbf{S} = \mathbf{E} \times \mathbf{H} \]
Understand how energy flux is directed perpendicular to \( \mathbf{E} \) and \( \mathbf{B} \)
Analyze applications in waveguides, antennas, and radiative energy transfer.

cards.title: Electromagnetic Wave Propagation
cards.description: Deriving the wave equation from Maxwell's equations.
bulletpoints: Express the wave equation in free space: \[ \nabla^2 \mathbf{E} = \mu_0 \epsilon_0 \frac{\partial^2 \mathbf{E}}{\partial t^2} \]
Understand how solutions take the form \[ \mathbf{E}(x,t) = E_0 e^{i(kx - \omega t)} \]
Analyze polarization, reflection, and transmission of electromagnetic waves.

cards.title: Plasma Electrodynamics & Magnetohydrodynamics
cards.description: Understanding how charged particle fluids interact with electromagnetic fields.
bulletpoints: Use the plasma continuity equation: \[ \frac{\partial n}{\partial t} + \nabla \cdot (n \mathbf{v}) = 0 \]
Analyze the motion of charged particles in magnetized plasmas via the Lorentz force.
Explore applications in controlled nuclear fusion and space plasma physics.

cards.title: Electromagnetic Potentials & Gauge Theory
cards.description: Exploring the role of potentials in electrodynamics and quantum field theory.
bulletpoints: Define the vector potential \( \mathbf{A} \) and scalar potential \( \phi \) such that \[ \mathbf{B} = \nabla \times \mathbf{A}, \quad \mathbf{E} = - \nabla \phi - \frac{\partial \mathbf{A}}{\partial t} \]
Understand gauge transformations and their role in simplifying equations.
Explore applications in quantum electrodynamics (QED) and superconductivity.
